data.title: Things to do in the Chattanooga area this weekend include Buskers Festival, Cherokee cultural celebration
data.meta_description: From artillery demonstrations and a celebration of Cherokee culture to free movie nights and the Chattanooga Market's Buskers Festival, there's plenty to do this weekend. Here's the chronology.
data.text:
From artillery demonstrations and a celebration of Cherokee culture to free movie nights and the Chattanooga Market's Buskers Festival, there's plenty to do this weekend. Here's the chronology.

ARTS

— Photographic Society of Chattanooga continues its summer show at the Gallery at Blackwell, 71 Eastgate Loop. Society members have their work displayed, and prints are available for purchase. Gallery hours are 7:30 a.m.-5:30 p.m. Monday-Friday. The exhibition will run through Aug. 23. Learn more at chattanoogaphoto.org.

— Creative Arts Guild, 520 W. Waugh St., Dalton, continues two exhibitions. In Gallery Five20, there is "Samuel Shootingstar: A Whimsical Space Adventure," featuring works by Adam Sanford. In Gallery One11, there is "The Pointillism of Life," featuring works by Rick Watts. Gallery hours are 10 a.m.-7 p.m. Monday-Thursday, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Friday and by appointment Saturday-Sunday. The exhibitions will run through Aug. 30. Learn more at creativeartsguild.org.

— Area 61 Gallery, 721 Broad St., Suite 100, continues its exhibition, "Soaring," featuring works by Erica Moreland who was inspired by an abstraction of wings. Gallery hours are noon-6 p.m. Monday, Thursday-Sunday and by appointment Tuesday-Wednesday. The exhibition will run through September. Learn more at area61gallery.com.

— In-Town Gallery, 26A Frazier Ave., will host an opening reception from 5-9 p.m. Friday for its exhibition, "Home and Away," featuring works by guest artist Suzanne Mortimer. Gallery hours are 11 a.m.-6 p.m. Monday-Saturday and noon-5 p.m. Sunday. The exhibition will run through Aug. 31. Learn more at intowngallery.com.

— Association for Visual Arts, 30 Frazier Ave., will host an opening reception from 6-9 p.m. Friday for its juried member exhibition. Gallery hours are noon-5 p.m. Wednesday-Thursday, noon-6 p.m. Friday-Saturday and noon-5 p.m. Sunday. The exhibition will run through Sept. 20. Learn more at avarts.org.

— Hunter Museum of American Art, 10 Bluff View, will host "Art Deco Dreams" from 2-4 p.m. Sunday. Children and families can enjoy drop-in art experiences, making their own creations inspired by the museum's current exhibition, "Art Deco Glass." Regular admission of $20 applies. Youth 17 and under get in free. Learn more at huntermuseum.org.

COMEDY

— The Seed Theatre and Improv Chattanooga will present "The Unrehearsed, Untold, Untrue Story of..." at 2 and 5 p.m. Sunday at Barking Legs Theater, 1307 Dodds Ave. Tickets cost $15. Learn more at barkinglegs.org.

FILM

— Signal Mountain Parks and Recreation Board will host its inaugural dive-in movie night at 8:30 p.m. Friday at the town pool, 1111 Ridgeway Ave., Signal Mountain. The night's movie will be "Angels in the Outfield;" the film is rated PG. Concessions will be available. Admission costs $5 per person. Learn more at facebook.com/TownofSignalMountain.

— Hamilton County Parks and Recreation will host a beach movie night from 3-11 p.m. Saturday at Chester Frost Park beach, 2277 Gold Point Circle N., Hixson. The night's movie will be "Jaws: The Revenge;" the film is rated PG-13. There will be food trucks, a cornhole tournament, games, face painting and more. The movie will screen at 9 p.m. Learn more at facebook.com/HamCoTNParks.

— Collegedale Parks and Recreation will host a free movie in a park event at 6:30 p.m. Saturday at Little Debbie Park, 4698 Swinyar Drive, Collegedale. There will be activities and food trucks at 6:30 p.m., and the movie, "Toy Story," will screen around 9 p.m. The movie is rated G. Learn more at collegedaleparksandrec.com.

MUSIC

— Barrelhouse Ballroom, 1501 Long St., will have multiple shows through the week's end. At 9 p.m. Wednesday, there will be Wubs a Month, an electronic bass night; tickets cost $10 in advance or $15 the day of show. At 9 p.m. Friday, there will be Boot Scootin' Boogie Nights, a night of '90s country; tickets cost $15 in advance or $20 the day of show. At 2 p.m. Saturday, there will be Jerry Fest, a celebration of Jerry Garcia and the Grateful Dead that will also feature local vendors and more; tickets cost $25 in advance or $30 the day of show. Learn more at barrelhouseballroom.com.

— Songbirds, 206 W. Main St., will have two shows going into the weekend. At 7 p.m. Thursday, there will be an open mic night for local musicians; only 10 spots are available on a first-come, first-serve basis, starting at 6 p.m. At 8 p.m. Saturday, Chattanooga singer-songwriter Klark Kint will perform; general admission costs $29. Learn more at songbirdsfoundation.org.

— The Signal, 21 Choo Choo Ave., will have two shows going into the weekend. At 8 p.m. Thursday, Cinderella's Tom Keifer Band, with L.A. Guns, will perform; tickets start at $37.50. At 9 p.m. Saturday, there will be No Scrubs, a '90s dance party; tickets start at $18. Learn more at thesignaltn.com.

— Nightfall, an outdoor summer concert series, continues for the season, beginning at 6 p.m. Friday at Miller Park, 928 Market St. This week's concert will feature The Foothills as the opener and Parker Millsap as the headliner. An art market will open at 6 p.m., and food trucks will start selling at 6:30 p.m. There will be children's activities, including an inflatable soccer field. For adults, there will be a Nightfall Happy Hour, featuring weekly drink specials, from 5:30-6:30 p.m. Learn more at nightfallchattanooga.com.

— Chattanooga Girls Choir will have in-person open registration from 1-4 p.m. Saturday at First Christian Church, 650 McCallie Ave. Those interested in joining the choir may complete their placement singing and all paperwork at once. Learn more at chattanoogagirlschoir.org.

— Riverfront Nights, a free summer concert series, continues for the season from 6-10 p.m. Saturday at Ross's Landing, 201 Riverfront Parkway. The Essentials will be the opener, and Back 2 Mac, a Fleetwood Mac tribute, will be the headliner. Concession and drink sales begin at 6 p.m. Learn more at riverfrontnights.com.

OUT & ABOUT

— Nooga Splash continues through Sept. 28 at Chester Frost Park, 2277 Gold Point Circle N., Hixson. The all-ages floating water park features a 35-section inflatable obstacle course. Operating hours are 11 a.m.-8 p.m. Sundays-Fridays and 10 a.m.-8 p.m. Saturdays. Standard admission starts at $22. Learn more at noogasplash.com.

— The Point Church will host a Blessing of the Backpacks service from 5-7 p.m. Wednesday at its Signal Mountain campus, 939 Ridgeway Ave. The church will pray for students, teachers and administrators. Dinner will be served at 5:30 p.m. and will be followed by a time of prayer and worship. Learn more at pointchurch.org.

— The Conversation will be from 3-5 p.m. Friday at the Edney Innovation Center, 1100 Market St. The event will feature a discussion by four panelists: Marvin Bodley, Elenora Woods, Tiffany Adams and Cameron Williams, speaking on a subject of their choice, with an open forum for discussion with attendees. Seating is limited; food and beverages will be provided. Admission costs $20. For more information, contact Jamar Harden at 423-320-9542.

— Chattanooga Toy Collectibles Show and Cruise-In will take place from 9 a.m.-2 p.m. (collectibles) and 4-7 p.m. (cruise-in) Saturday at Camp Jordan Arena, 323 Camp Jordan Parkway, East Ridge. The show will feature vendors with a large variety of collectibles, while the cruise-in will feature classic cars, imported vehicles, trucks, motorcycles and more. Local craft and food vendors will be on-site. Entry fee is $5; children 12 and under get in free. Proceeds from entrance fees will benefit the East Ridge Needy Child Fund. Learn more at nickelcast.com/home.

— McKamey Animal Center will host its Doggie Pool Pawty from 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday at Carver Recreation Center, 649 N. Orchard Knob Ave. The summer celebration will allow owners to splash around the pool with their dogs. The event is divided into three splash sessions: 10-11:30 a.m., 11:45 a.m.-1:15 p.m. and 1:30-3 p.m. Cost is $20 per dog; tickets are limited. Learn more at bit.ly/McPoolPawty.

— Chattanooga River Market will be from 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Saturday at the Tennessee Aquarium Plaza, 1 Broad St. The market features a variety of vendors selling handmade arts, crafts and food. The river market will be open Saturdays only through October. Learn more at chattanoogamarket.com.

— Red Clay State Historic Park, 1140 Red Clay Park Road S.W., Cleveland, Tenn., will host the Cherokee Cultural Celebration from 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Saturday-Sunday. The event will immerse attendees in the history and culture of the Cherokee through music, dancing, demonstrations, crafts, food and more. Admission costs $5 per vehicle. Learn more at facebook.com/RedClayStateHistoricPark.

— Tennessee Valley Model Railroaders will host a free open house from 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Saturday at the Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum, 4119 Cromwell Road. The group will have its HO-scale layout on display. Learn more at tvmri.org.

— Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park will present "An Abyss of Lurid Darkness" Saturday at Point Park, 110 Point Park Road, Lookout Mountain. As part of the presentation, there will be artillery firing demonstrations at 10:30 and 11:30 a.m. and 1:30, 2:30 and 3:30 p.m. inside the park. The demonstrations will also provide attendees with insight about artillery history during the Civil War's "Battle Above the Clouds." Park admission costs $10 for adults; youth 15 and under get in free. Learn more at nps.gov/chch.

— Friends of the Gordon-Lee Mansion will host self-guided tours from 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday at the mansion, 217 Cove Road, Chickamauga. Tours will take place Saturdays through Labor Day weekend. Admission costs $5 for adults and $1 for children 12 and under. Proceeds support the improvement and enhancement of the mansion. Learn more at friendsofthegordonleemansion.org.

— Whitfield-Murray Historical Society will conclude its summer Second Saturday events with guided tours from 1-4 p.m. Saturday at the Chatsworth Depot, 219 N. First Ave., Chatsworth. There will be tours of the depot as well as the Wright Hotel. Thomas the Tank Engine will make a special appearance, and the historical society is celebrating the hotel's 115th anniversary with special displays and souvenirs. Second Saturdays are free, and donations are accepted. Learn more at whitfield-murrayhistoricalsociety.org.

— Chattanooga Market will host its Buskers Festival from 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Sunday at First Horizon Pavilion, 1801 Reggie White Blvd. In addition to a variety of vendors, food trucks and live music, there will be street performers scattered around the market. Learn more at chattanoogamarket.com.

— Back to School Bash will be from noon-6 p.m. Sunday at the Commons, 4750 Swinyar Drive, Collegedale. There will be waterslides, food, vendors, live music and more. Attendees can enter to win a backpack full of back to school goodies. Learn more at a5images.org/upcoming-events.

SPORTS

— Chattanooga Red Wolves will have a home game against the Spokane Velocity at 7:30 p.m. Wednesday at CHI Memorial Stadium, 1 Stadium Way, East Ridge. Game promotions include: $2 beer night and fireworks. General admission tickets cost $17. Learn more at chattanoogaredwolves-sc.com.

— Pro Wrestling Inside and Out will present Championship Wrestling: The Quest at 8 p.m. Friday at the Agricultural Center on the Walker County Civic Center campus, 10052 N. Highway 27, Rock Spring. The event will feature 16 wrestlers seeking to advance to become champion. The event will be presented in a traditional and classic style, with focus on the sport of wrestling rather than the entertainment most have become accustomed to. Tickets cost $10 in advance or $15 the day of the event. Learn more at prowrestlinginsideandout.net.

THEATER

— Conasauga Shakespeare Coalition will present a production of "Romeo and Juliet" at 8 p.m. Friday-Saturday at Prater's Mill Historic Site, 5845 Highway 2, Dalton. The production is set against the backdrop of the American Revolution, with the feuding Montague and Capulet families reimagined as patriot and loyalist families. Admission costs $15 for adults and $10 for students and seniors. There will be additional performances Aug. 16-17. Learn more at conasaugashakespeare.com.

Find more events, and add your own, at timesfreepress.com/cnevents.
